results.title: Fireman Sam
results.creator_credit: John Walker, Ian Frampton and Bumper Film
results.brief_description: Four stories featuring Fireman Sam and his friends in the town of Pontypandy narrated by John Alderton. The first story shows what happens when a trick is played on the fireman as a sticky substance is smeared on the fireman pole. There is a cat stuck up a tree in the second episode, a camping trip in the third and a special appearance on television by the Station Officer which excites the locals.

results.title: Fire on Heimaey
results.brief_description: This film shows the eruption on Heimaey Island: the eruption threatened to destroy Iceland’s most important fishing centre. The film also shows how the townspeople halted the devastation.

results.title: Fire of time
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Urban development in Barcelona has all but destroyed the once vibrant Barrio Chino where the nights were days and the days were long. This is an evocative film shot through windows, on street corners and in small rooms. People, clouds, and the swift tail lights of cars glide past and through, as fleeting traces of the passage of time. And as this one working-class Red Light district is transformed and changed by the process of gentrification, the former residents appear as ghosts, their prescence - as graffiti, as shadows - a reminder of the real history of the city. Larger forces cause buildings and neighbourhoods to vanish but they are rebuilt again in memories, worn photographs and in light. Adam Cohen’s handling of light gives people the substance of phantoms and their passages through the half deserted streets evoke Eliot, Proust, and Chris Marker. Sounds of this world are orchestrated with cello, organ and guitar to form a profoundly beautiful work about memory, longing and loss.

results.creator_credit: David Williams and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: A short animated film where a sassy kid and a klutzy dragon defeat the renovation plans of the evil Count Plastic.

results.title: Fine feathers
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this cut-out colour cartoon by film artist Evelyn Lambart, two quarrelsome birds get the urge to change their plumage. A bluejay wants to be decked out in the green of the cedar, and a loon in the burnished red of oak leaves. There is a moral to the story. Neither bird had reckoned on the consequences of vanity. Along comes a gust of wind and both learn to their consternation that their natural, well-anchored feathers offered better protection.

results.title: Eureka
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Through dramatised re-enactments, as well as historical footage, Bill Peach traces the events which led to the dramatic confrontation at the Eureka stockade, one of the key incidents in Australian political history. He investigates the issues behind the uprising between the miners, the police and the army caused by harsh and expensive licensing systems and describes how long-term effects eventually led to the introduction of safer and fairer working conditions.

results.title: Golden age
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, Bill Peach investigates the developments on the goldfields that occurred within ten years of the first Australian gold rushes. No longer was it just the lone miner scrabbling away at the rockface - big companies and massive machines replaced the small digger, with more gold found deep underground. The entire population benefitted through the development of transportation methods such as coach lines and railways needed to move the greater volumes of material, and the growth of cities like Melbourne - a boom town built on gold.

results.title: Peach's gold
results.brief_description: Bill Peach describes how the discovery of gold changed the course of Australia’s history. Through dramatised re-enactments and historical footage, the effects of the new economic force on population, the location of towns, wealth generation, the development of transport networks and the introduction of a representative democracy are all investigated. In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.
results.description: Bill Peach describes how the discovery of gold changed the course of Australia’s history. In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.

results.title: Life on the goldfields
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Bill Peach presents a look at life on the goldfields after the Eureka stockade. It was a colourful but often violent time, where fortunes were made and lost in a heartbeat. Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, the point is made that not all of those who came to the goldfields were fortunate enough to realise their dream, however they almost always embodied the pioneer spirit. Out of this free-wheeling era emerged the beginnings of a new society.

results.title: Land of gold
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, Bill Peach investigates the economic crash of the 1890s and the exhaustion of the goldfields at Ballarat and Bendigo. He describes how the less well known but far more productive goldfields at Coolgardie and Kalgoorlie rescued Australia from the depths of depression and continued to contribute to the country’s economy up to the early 1980s.
